Title: What comes down must go up (at least in terms of prices)


In my opinion this graph is misleading. By just glancing at this graph, one would think that the price of gas and vehicles has gotten higher every month. But because the graph is compared to the previous years prices, this is untrue. While it is true that prices for these things have gone up, because they were so low at the same time the previous year, the are about the same that they were before the pandemic started. This trend is consistent more or less throughout the graph. Also, because the prices are not compared to the previous months, they are not going up month to month, they are only higher compared to last years prices. Also most of these products have reasons other than inflation for their increase in price e.g. televisions because of the perceived shortage of computer chips, gasoline because of the increase in oil prices, and used vehicles because of the shortage of chips to make new vehicle, limiting the supply of new vehicles, thus creating a higher demand for used vehicles. name: William Barker
comment info:
A1:Inflation of prices seems to be widespread throughout these products and services. Some products are observing severe price inflation like gas and used cars. A lot of recent trends can likely be explained by the Coronavirus pandemic because under the pandemic people were not buying as many products and services because of the stay-at-home order and economic crisis. This is shown especially with the price of gasoline, as it experienced a large amount of deflation in 2020, as people weren’t driving as much to go places. But in 2021, as the mask mandate has lifted, places are reopening, and people are returning to their job sites the demand for gasoline is much greater than in 2020. The same explanation can be used for sports equipment, as the pandemic restricted and decreased the amount of sports activity.
A2:What is making television begin to go up in price again? What is responsible for the recent inflation in home furniture? What part of the pandemic made chicken’s price inflate in 2020? How are lower-income people ever going to be able to afford a car if both used car and truck prices and gas prices are rapidly inflating? 
A3:These are all products we consume, and in some cases rely on. The affordability of products directly affects the living conditions of our residents and their economic situation. If prices continue to inflate for most products it’ll be harder for people to live.
A4:Everything is expensive now? Why is inflation so prevalent in our recovering world?

name: Lisa
comment info: I noticed in the past few years, technology devices such as televisions' prices have been dropping. It makes sense because currently, countries are massively producing technology devices since we rely on them a lot. However, past the year 2021, many products and services have been raising their prices due to the shortage supplied. Lots of factories were shut down due to COVID and haven't been able to function again. Gasoline is a daily need for human lives so when there is a shortage of it, companies are willing to raise the prices because it is most likely an essential need. I also wonder about chicken price and how it has been rising since 2020. Was there an increasing amount of demand for chicken these years? If the price of chickens already looks like this then the price of beef must have increased in a larger amount because it costs a lot to farm cows.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Lisa Ya I wonder why the chicken prices have inflated as well its strange.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Lisa To address your question about chicken prices, it is supply chain issues that are causing a low supply. Remeber when several meat processing plants were getting shut down as a result of working contracting Covid-18? This is a far reaching ramifications. Suppliers of meat, (Farms), had to cull livestock as there was no place to take their product. Now the supply chain is behind as there is a lack of product that would have already been in the loop and being process now erased. Processing plants are no longer issue, they are caught up but there is a lack of product for them to process. Additionally, truck driver shortages across the country have led to longer wait times and cancelled deliveries for many products. Food happens to be one of the product lines most effected by the truck driver shortage.

name: Thomaz
comment info:
As COVID-19 has affected supply and demand in many markets, it is possible to discern a pattern across the price changes in this graph. For example, I noticed that the price of sports equipment has gone up recently, which is likely due to the fact that sports teams and recreational sports activities have seen a return to action recently as vaccines have come out. In my community and many other communities, public school sports teams have been brought back. I also noticed that the price of used cars and trucks have gone up as well, which may be due to the fact that more and more people are traveling by car, again due to the release of a COVID-19 vaccine. name: Maria Fernanda Correa
comment info:
U.S. economy still positive for Covid19.
The pandemic has hit the world economy hard. Even the economically most prosperous countries are still not recovering, and this is what we are currently seeing with inflation in the United States. The graph shows how prices have skyrocketed by 10% to 20% in the cost of gasoline, home furniture, some foods such as chicken, sports equipment, and new and used vehicles. The shortage of these products is the leading cause of the price increase due to global supply chains and the lack of people to enter the workforce. 
This economic phenomenon can bring significant consequences for the world economy. The planet continues to show us how vulnerable our economic systems are. Therefore, We should take advantage of this opportunity and this financial crisis to seek alternative solutions that can allow us to move forward.
In the case of the increase in the price of vehicles and gasoline, many governments could be motivating their citizens to purchase electric cars, whose maintenance is much cheaper and environmentally friendly. Moreover, the oil industry should be reduced or ended soon for the benefit of all.
Another essential aspect that we as citizens can consider is to promote local purchasing. Many local food producers, farmer markets, and even the local furniture industry need support. Opting for these and not for imported products instead would be contributing to lessening the impact of the economic crisis.

comment info:
What do I notice?: I notice that this graph shows changes in prices in various categories over the last few years. It seems that the graph predicts prices for 2022 as well. Gasoline shows the highest increase, and eyeglasses and eye care have seen the least increase in prices. I notice that the categories don't really seem to be related to each other in any way, except for gasoline and used vehicles.

What do you wonder?: I wonder why these specific categories of products were chosen. Chicken and eyeglasses don't seem to fit into the same category as all the other products, so I'm interested in why they were added. Were these categories chosen by importance, or by how many were sold?

What impacts does this have on you and your community?: This impacts me because these are all relatively common products my family and I buy. My mom owns a car and buys gasoline, and I recently got new glasses. Because we purchase products like these, we can plan ahead to see what may be more affordable or expensive now.

What's going on in this graph?: This graph shows seven different categories of products and uses colors and arrows to show whether they have decreased or increased in price as compared to twelve months prior. It uses red to signify an increase in price and blue for a decrease. it shows prices starting in 2019. The products with the most change in prices are televisions, used trucks and cars, and gasoline. A good title for this graph could be "Price Changes Throughout The Years"
